title: Transformations - Add field from calculation: add Logic operators to Binary operation
body:
<!-- Please only use this template for submitting feature requests -->

**Why is this needed**:
The ‚ÄúAdd field from calculation‚Äù transformation supports only mathematical functions, but in many cases it is necessary to create a new field using basic logical operators. For example, creating a field C = 1 if Field A > Field B, and so on.

**What would you like to be added**:
Add logic operators to "Add field from calculation" transformation. It could be just extend binary operators with < > == and != operators. 
The closest example is the IF function in MySQL, which many people currently use to implement basic logic at the DataSource layer.

**Who is this feature for?**
Most users rely on a workaround by moving any logic to the data source layer, for example to MySQL or Infinity. 
However, when working with a Prometheus data source ‚Äî or especially with mixed queries from different data sources such as Prometheus and SQL together ‚Äî this quickly becomes painful and, in some cases, even impossible. And all that you have left for data processing and aggregation are "transformations".

For example, I would like to color table cell A based on the value of table cell B.
This is a simple and commonly requested operation: you need to display some data in one cell, but highlight it based on an additional external condition. The internet has been full of questions about how to do this for more than five years, yet there is still no clear or proper solution.
‚ÄúConfig from query results‚Äù could solve this problem. However, if you cannot create an intermediate field based on a logical condition, then ‚ÄúConfig from query results‚Äù becomes useless for this use case. 

Without logical operations, we are forced to use such a terrible mathematical expression to implement a simple logical function A > B.
flag = max( min( (A - B) / abs(A - B), 1 ), 0 )

title: Dashboards: when using mixed ds, properties does not properly reset when switching query datasources, potentially causing invalid queries
body:
In mixed mode, if a datasource sets the the `format` property of a target to 1, and the datasource is then changed to prometheus, `format: 1` will remain. The prometheus backend does not accept 1 as a valid format and can't unmarshal.

Unless a user is selecting the exact same datasource plugin, we probably need to clear all the properties.

Another option is to fix datasources that are using the wrong type for properties like format that are widely used.

title: Geomap panel snaps back to "inital view‚Äù on dashboard refresh - but only with ‚Äúfit to data‚Äù view.
body:
### What happened?

When I use a Geomap panel with ‚Äúinitial view‚Äù set to **_coordinates_**, you can zoom and pan around the map once the dashboard has loaded - all good. A dashboard refresh has no affect. This is good.

But if I set the ‚Äúinitial view‚Äù to **_fit-to-data_** then on each dashboard refresh the map snaps back to the initial view, which is really annoying if users want to pan around the area after the dashboard has loaded. "Initial view" is no longer just the initial view - it's the "on every refresh" view.

_**Note**: where I mention _refresh_ here, this is referring to a Grafana Dashboard refresh. not a browser or page refresh._

It seems odd that these two view options give a different user experience.

The **_coordinates_** way is much better.

### What did you expect to happen?

I would expect the map panel Initial View to work the same way, regardless of whether the initial view is set to **_coordinates_** or **_fit-to-data_**.

The initial view should be just that... **just the initial view** when the dashboard loads. The map should not snap back to this view on every refresh.

This doesn't give a great user experience. And asking our users to switch off the refresh on a dashboard before zooming is also not ideal and not a great experience for them.

### Did this work before?

Not sure. I've tried a few versions, and they're all the same. Even in Grafana Play it is the same (see below).

### How do we reproduce it?

The quickest way to reproduce this is with Grafana Play:

1. Open the Geomap example in Grafana Play: https://play.grafana.org/d/panel-geomap/geomap-examples
2. Set the dashboard refresh to 10 seconds (the default is "off")
3. Zoom out or pan the map to another area.
4. You will notice here that nothing changes each 10 seconds - the map area stays as you've zoomed / panned. This is OK.
5. **But....**
6. Now edit one of the Geomap panels and change Initial View (in Map View) from "coordinates" to "fit to data".
7. Go back to the dashboard.
8. Zoom out or pan the map to another area (same as in step 4).
9. The difference now is that every 10 seconds, the map snaps back to the "initial view" (in fact they all do because "share view" has been enabled in this example dashboard).
10. _As a further example, you can deactivate the "share view" option on some panels - and see the different behaviour at the same time in two different panels._

Grafana: 12.2.1 (local) or Grafana Play
OS: Windows 11
Browser: Chrome and Edge (both give same result)

Docker

title: Grafana fails to start completely when provisioned alert rule references non-existent receiver
body:
### What happened?

## Summary
When an alert rule is provisioned (e.g., via ConfigMap) that references a contact point/receiver that doesn't exist, Grafana fails to start entirely. This is overly disruptive behavior ‚Äî a single misconfigured alert rule should not prevent the entire Grafana instance from starting.

## Actual Behavior
Grafana refuses to start with error:
```
level=error msg="Failed to provision alerting" error="alert rules: invalid alert rule\nreceiver MyFancyAlertChannel does not exist"
Error: ‚úó invalid service state: Failed, expected: Terminated, failure: invalid service state: Failed, expected: Running
```

## Impact
This behavior is particularly problematic in multi-tenant or platform scenarios where:
- Teams are allowed to define their own alerts via provisioning (GitOps)
- A single team's misconfiguration brings down the shared Grafana instance for everyone
- Recovery requires manual intervention to fix or remove the faulty configuration



### What did you expect to happen?

## Expected Behavior
Grafana should start successfully and either:
- Log a warning/error about the invalid receiver reference
- Disable or skip the misconfigured alert rule
- Fall back to a default receiver

The invalid alert rule should **not** prevent the entire application from starting.

## Suggested Improvement
- Implement graceful degradation: start Grafana but mark invalid alert rules as broken/disabled
- Provide clear visibility in the UI for misconfigured rules
- Consider a "strict mode" flag for environments that prefer fail-fast behavior

### Did this work before?

I don't think so.

### How do we reproduce it?

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a contact point via the Grafana UI (e.g., `MyFancyAlertChannel`)
2. Provision an alert rule via ConfigMap/file provisioning that references this UI-created contact point
3. Redeploy/restart Grafana (the UI-created contact point is not persisted in provisioning and is lost)
4. Grafana fails to start

title: TraceQL recording rules: inconsistencies between labeling conventions between mimir and tempo cause err-mimir-label-invalid errors
body:
### What happened?

Because tempo has a dot notation convention for labels, and mimir has an underscore convention, when we try to create Traceql recording rule (https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/104289) that includes a label with a dot (or other invalid mimir label character), then the recording rule throws err-mimir-label-invalid.

For example this TraceQL will succeed:

`
{ resource.service.name="my-most-excellent-service"}  | max_over_time(span:duration) by (name) 
`
However these TraceQL will throw:
`
{ resource.service.name="my-most-excellent-service"} | max_over_time(span:duration) by (.span.kind)
`
`
{ resource.service.name="my-most-excellent-service"} | max_over_time(span:duration) by (span:kind)
`





### What did you expect to happen?

I think the most elegant solution here would be for TraceQL to support some kind of label rename at query time, then I could explicitly provide a mimir-safe label name; I didn't find that or similar feature request on the Tempo backlog...  maybe a less elegant solution would be to coerce invalid characters to underscores?  

Any thoughts/advice on the matter will be appreciated, thanks!
   Ryan

### Did this work before?

N/A

### How do we reproduce it?

1. Create a TraceQL recording rule a la https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/104289
2. Use a query like so
`
{ resource.service.name="my-most-excellent-service"} | max_over_time(span:duration) by (span:kind)
`

3. Observe the error:
`
remote write failed: series was rejected: received a series with an invalid label: 'resource.service.name' series: 'test_recording_rule_delete_me_DEVOPS_231715{jenkins_computer_name="{{ $labels.span.jenkins.computer.name }}", resource.service.name="\"trident-controller\""}' (err-mimir-label-invalid)
`

title: Alerting: Support reusable query templates with placeholders in the UI
body: ### **What problem are you trying to solve?** In Grafana Alerting, alert rules require each team or service to define its own query logic, even when the underlying condition is conceptually the same. This leads to: ‚Ä¢ duplicated alert queries across teams, ‚Ä¢ inconsistencies in how similar alerts are implemented, ‚Ä¢ high maintenance cost when a common query needs to be updated, ‚Ä¢ reliance on copying/pasting queries instead of reusing shared definitions. Grafana currently lacks a first-class mechanism to reuse alert query logic across alert rules. ‚∏ª ### **Important clarification**: this is NOT about dashboard template variables Several existing issues and discussions focus on supporting dashboard template variables in alert queries. The following issues and discussions are often referenced in relation to templating in alerting, but they do not fully address the use case described here: ‚Ä¢ #6557 ‚Äì ‚ÄúAlerting support for queries using template variables‚Äù ‚Ä¢ #9334 ‚Äì ‚ÄúAlerting with template variables‚Äù ‚Ä¢ #16681 ‚Äì ‚ÄúAlerting does not support template variables‚Äù ‚Ä¢ #36110 ‚Äì ‚ÄúTemplate variables are not supported in alert queries‚Äù ‚Ä¢ Discussion #39249 ‚Äì ‚ÄúAllow Template Variables To Be Used in Alert Queries‚Äù ‚Ä¢ #76596 ‚Äì ‚ÄúAdd variable interpolation when creating alert rule from panel‚Äù üëâ None of the above propose a UI-level concept of reusable alert query templates with placeholders, defined once and instantiated multiple times with different values. This proposal addresses a different and more general problem. ‚∏ª ### **Proposed solution** Introduce Query Templates as a first-class concept in Grafana Alerting. A query template would: ‚Ä¢ Define a query once (PromQL, LogQL, etc.) ‚Ä¢ Contain explicit placeholders (e.g. ${service}, ${namespace}, ${cluster}) ‚Ä¢ Be stored and managed centrally ‚Ä¢ Be selectable from the Alert Rule UI When a user selects a query template: ‚Ä¢ The UI detects placeholders ‚Ä¢ The UI prompts for values ‚Ä¢ The alert rule is instantiated from the template + provided values ‚∏ª Example `sum by (pod) ( rate(container_cpu_usage_seconds_total{ namespace="${namespace}", container!="", pod=~"${service}.*" }[5m]) )` ### **Alert rule creation** The UI prompts for: ‚Ä¢ namespace: payments ‚Ä¢ service: checkout Result: ‚Ä¢ Consistent alert logic ‚Ä¢ No query duplication ‚Ä¢ Easy reuse across services It could look like something like this ‚∏ª Benefits ‚Ä¢ Reuse of alert logic across teams ‚Ä¢ Consistency in alert definitions ‚Ä¢ Lower barrier for teams less familiar with query languages ‚Ä¢ Centralized ownership of alert patterns ‚Ä¢ Reduced maintenance cost This is particularly valuable for common infrastructure alerts, such as: ‚Ä¢ Kubernetes CPU / memory usage per service ‚Ä¢ Error rate alerts ‚Ä¢ Latency SLO alerts ‚Ä¢ Queue or consumer lag alerts ‚∏ª Summary While previous issues focus on enabling dashboard template variables in alert queries, this proposal introduces a different abstraction: reusable, centrally defined alert query templates with placeholders, instantiated via the alerting UI. This would significantly improve alert consistency, reuse, and maintainability in Grafana.

title: Support dynamic thresholds in Time series or other panels based on query fields or datasource values or dashboard variables
body:
Grafana Time Series panels currently support only static numeric threshold values configured at the panel level. There is no supported way to derive threshold values dynamically from query results or datasource fields (e.g., values returned from Elasticsearch).

In use cases where threshold values vary per series or depend on data returned by the query, this limitation prevents accurate visual representation and requires hard-coding values.

It would be very useful if Grafana could support:
‚óè Setting thresholds from query fields or variables.
‚óè Applying per-series threshold values dynamically
Or
‚óè Allowing thresholds to be updated programmatically based on datasource data
‚óè Applying thresholds based on the dashboard variables.

This would greatly improve flexibility for dashboards built on Elasticsearch and similar data sources.
